content: Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Automation in Construction journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/autcon A sound monitoring system for prevention of underground pipeline damage caused by construction Zelong Liua, Suzhen Lia,b,⁎ a Tongji University, College of Civil Engineering, Siping 1239, Shanghai 200092, China b Tongji University, State Key Laboratory of Disaster Reduction in Civil Engineering, Siping 1239, Shanghai 200092, China A R T I C L E I N F O Keywords: Construction Underground pipeline Sound monitoring Mel frequency cepstrum coeﬃcients Random forest A B S T R A C T Construction activities have become a common cause of underground pipeline accidents. The detection of construction activities near pipelines based on acoustic signals can eﬀectively reduce pipeline damage. In the framework of “collecting data—feature extraction—classiﬁer training—monitoring scheme”, this paper presents a construction sound monitoring system to prevent the underground pipeline damage caused by construction. The construction sounds of electric hammers, road cutters and excavator breaking hammers are collected as well as environmental noise. A double-layer identiﬁcation scheme consisting of two random forest-based classiﬁers makes up the core of the system. The classiﬁer-1 is ﬁrst established to detect suspicious sounds. Cutting out the suspected segments as inputs, the classiﬁer-2 is then trained to correct the results of the classiﬁer-1 and further identify the types of construction activities. In the test, 95.59% of the construction sounds near pipelines are detected, while only 1.12% of environmental noise causes false positives. 1. Introduction Construction activities have seriously jeopardized the safety of un- derground pipelines. According to the statistical data on pipeline ac- cidents in China, the United States [1] and Europe [2], those caused by civil construction account for 68%, 29.8% and 28% of all pipeline ac- cidents respectively. Such grim statistics call for eﬀective measures to stop construction activities that pose a threat to pipelines. The most common measures in engineering practice to prevent the construction threats is to set up warning boards, caution tapes or one- call systems [3]. These passive measures, however, highly depend on subjective cooperation between construction workers and pipeline companies. To enhance the ability of active supervision, more techni- ques have been recently developed for real-time monitoring of con- struction activities near pipelines. According to the types of the col- lected signals, the common monitoring methods can be divided into vibration monitoring, video/image monitoring, electrical signal mon- itoring and acoustic signal monitoring. Vibration signals generated by construction can be collected by optical ﬁber [4–7], static sensing cable or multi-seismic sensors [8], which perform well in identifying and locating construction threats. However, the installation of the vibration monitoring system costs too much for the existing pipeline, as the sensors must be placed underground. The video/image monitoring system is generally used in perimeter warning of city gate stations with the ﬁxed cameras. It can also be applied to monitor construction activities by using image re- cognition technology to process aero-photograph [9], but the aircraft inspection is limited by weather condition and usually costs a lot. An- other method is to monitor excavation damage with the aid of the cathodic protection system [10]. However, the construction threats cannot cause signiﬁcant changes in the electrical signals. Using the acoustic signals recorded by microphones, Wan et al. propose a support vector machine (SVM) based method to identify the sound signals of the road cutter [11]. Compared with the three kinds of monitoring systems as mentioned earlier, the sound monitoring system has the advantages of simple arrangement, good applicability and accurate recognition, which shows

great potential for construction activity detection. The construction of smart cities and the machine learning tech- nology make important contributions to the researches and applications of sound monitoring systems. With the rapid development of informa- tion and communication technology (ICT) in recent years for smart city construction, various physical devices are installed and connected to the network (the Internet of things or IoT) to optimize the eﬃciency of city operations and services. Among them, acoustic sensors are also placed to monitor urban environmental noise [12,13], which brings convenience for signal collection of construction sound monitoring. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.autcon.2020.103125 Received 27 June 2019; Received in revised form 17 January 2020; Accepted 6 February 2020 ⁎ Corresponding author at: Tongji University, College of Civil Engineering and State Key Laboratory of Disaster Reduction in Civil Engineering, Siping 1239, Shanghai 200092, China. E-mail address: Lszh@tongji.edu.cn (S. Li). Autom ation in Construction 113 (2020) 103125 Available online 13 February 2020 0926-5805/ ©  2020 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. T Meanwhile, the accurate classiﬁcation of sounds is made possible for the explosive development of machine learning. The symbolic learning algorithm that mainly includes ID3, C4.5, CART and random forest [14] is an important branch of classiﬁcation algorithm for the ease of un- derstanding. With the advantages of accurate recognition, strong gen- eralization and fast classiﬁcation, the random forest algorithm is con- sidered as one of the best classiﬁcation algorithms [15]. Although great progresses have been made in the ﬁeld of sound monitoring systems, there are still some problems in the current re- searches. It is arduous for monitoring systems to identify diﬀerent types of construction activities, as the construction activities have many si- milarities in acoustic signals. The monitoring systems also face the challenges in reducing false alarms under diﬀerent environmental noise. It is necessary to establish a sound monitoring system that can identify multiple construction activities under common environmental noise. Considering the advantages of sound monitoring systems and the problems in the current researches, this paper proposes a random forest-based sound monitoring system for prevention of underground pipeline damage caused by construction, which can accurately identify three types of construction activities under common urban environ- mental noise. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents the arrangement and implement of ﬁeld testing, where the acoustic signals of construction activities and environmental noise are acquired and analyzed in time and frequency domain. The methodology of feature extraction and random forest-based classiﬁer training is proposed in the Section 3 and Section 4. Section 5 elaborates the monitoring strategy and testiﬁes the proposed monitoring system. In the end, the conclu- sions are drawn in Section 6. 2. Field tests for collection of sound signal samples 2.1. Field tests Field tests are ﬁrst conducted to collect sound signals under dif- ferent circumstances. The working sounds of electric hammers, road cutters and excavator breaking hammers are selected as the typical construction threats. The three types of environmental noise induced by pedestrian, traﬃc and wind are considered as the background noise of construction activities. In addition, the construction sounds without any environmental noise and the three types of environmental noise are also recorded for comparison. All these sound signals are collected by a recording device ICD-SX1000 and the sampling rate is set to 96 kHz. A 2.17-hour database so far composed of various records is created for further research with the details given in Table 1. (See Fig. 1.) 2.2. Sound signals in time and frequency domain The time series data of the threat sounds without

environmental noise is compared with that of environmental noise, and all the time series data are presented in Fig. 2. The acoustic signals of winds and road cutters have the largest amplitudes with the maximum values approaching 1. The amplitudes of the electric hammer records are mainly below 0.5, and those of the excavator breaking hammer records are roughly between 0 and 0.4. It is obvious that the amplitudes of pedestrian noise and traﬃc noise concentrating around 0–0.2 are smaller than other records. Using the information in the time series data, the acoustic signals of construction can be distinguished from the pedestrian noise and the traﬃc noise. However, due to the similarity in amplitude, it seems diﬃcult to separate wind noise and the sounds of road cutters in time series. The environmental noise and the acoustic signals of equipment in frequency domain are shown in Fig. 3. For the excavator breaking hammer, there are several peaks in the frequency spectrum when the frequency is lower than 2900 Hz, and the amplitude decreases at fre- quencies greater than 2900 Hz. The electric hammer has a maximum amplitude near 750 Hz, and after that the amplitude decreases as the frequency increases. The road cutter records have multiple peaks be- tween 0 and 15,000 Hz. The peak frequencies of pedestrian noise and traﬃc noise are below 200 Hz, while those of wind noise are within 0- 500 Hz. In general, the diﬀerences between the construction sounds and the environmental noise at high frequencies may provide a strong basis for identifying construction threats. 3. Acoustic feature extraction As the acoustic signals are short-term stationary, it is necessary to separate each signal into frames before extracting features. The speciﬁc method is to slide a ﬁxed-size window on the time series and to select the fragment within the window as a frame. In this paper, the size of the window is 20 ms (1920 values), and the sliding distance of the window is set to 10 ms (960 values). Hamming window function is applied to reduce the high-frequency signals caused by signal segmentation. All the frames can be given by: = × − × + ≤ ≤ y n Ham n x i s n n l ( ) ( ) [( 1) ], 1 i (1) where yi(n) is the n-th value of the i-th frame in time domain, Ham(n) is the Hamming window function x, is the acoustic signal to be divided, s is the distance of each sliding and l is the size of window. According to the signal analysis in Section 2, three features con- sisting of short-term energy, short-term zero-crossing rate and Mel- frequency cepstral coeﬃcients (MFCC) [16–18] are employed for sound recognition, as described below in details. 3.1. Short-term energy Short-term energy is the acoustic feature in time domain, commonly used in speech recognition to determine the starting point of speech. In this work, short-term energy is used to determine the starting and ending points of construction threat sounds. It is deﬁned as: ∑ = ∣ ∣ −∞ ∞ E y n ( ) t 2 (2) where Et is the short-term energy of a frame. The construction sounds without background noise and the three types of environmental noise are used to evaluate the short-time energy feature, as plotted in Fig. 4(a). It can be found that this feature is good at distinguishing the construction threats from pedestrian or traﬃc noise, but cannot eﬀectively distinguish the threats from wind noise. 3.2. The values of this feature are below 200 for the three kinds of ambient noise and over 500 for construction sounds. It conﬁrms that the short-term zero-crossing rate can eﬀectively distinguish construction threat sounds from wind noise, which can be used as a supplement to the short-term energy feature. 3.3. Mel frequency cepstral coeﬃcients MFCC is a feature in the frequency domain based on the mechanism of human auditory perception [19]. As shown in Fig. 5, the calculation process for MFCC includes the following steps: (1) Pre-emphasis processing is ﬁrst required to boost the high-fre- quency performance of acoustic signals. The signals are processed by a pre-emphasis ﬁlter that can be expressed as: = − − H n a y n ( ) 1 [ ( )] 1 (5) where y(n) is the frame to be ﬁltered and a is a constant generally set to 0.95. (3) The spectral energy of a frame is calculated by: = E k P k ( ) [ ( )]2 (7) (4) The energy spectrum of a frame in the frequency domain is ﬁltered by the Mel ﬁlter bank, and the energy in each Mel ﬁlter is given by: ∑ = ≤ ≤ = G e E k D k e M ( ) ( ) ( ), 1 k e 0 (8) where G(e) is the e-th Mel ﬁlter energy, De(k) is the ﬁlter function of the e-th bandpass ﬁlter and M is the total number of Mel ﬁlters generally taken as 12. (5) The logarithms of Mel ﬁlter energy in Eq. (8) are calculated and processed by the discrete cosine transform (DCT) for MFCC. Random forest model for classiﬁer training The classiﬁer generated by machine learning algorithms can iden- tify unknown acoustic signal samples based on the information in the training samples. A randomized training set containing sound samples of various conditions is very helpful to improve the quality of classiﬁer. Fig. 3. Acoustic signals in frequency domain. (a) Short-term energy (b) Short-term zero-crossing rate Fig. 4. Two features in time domain. Z. Liu and S. Li Autom ation in Construction 113 (2020) 103125 4 The training set in this paper consists of randomly selected samples of diﬀerent construction activities, environmental noise and distances between construction threats and microphones. The total number of training samples in the training set is 2400 (one 20 ms frame is used as one sample in this section), and the speciﬁc numbers of samples under diﬀerent conditions are shown in Table 2. Acoustic signals not selected as the training samples are used for the classiﬁer testing in Section 5, and the numbers of testing samples are presented in Table 3. Using the combination of sound features extracted in Section 3, two classiﬁers are trained based on the random forest algorithm. To dis- tinguish the construction sounds from the three types of environmental noise, the multi-feature vector formed by short-term energy and short- term zero-crossing rate is employed to train Classiﬁer-1. To dis- criminate diﬀerent construction threats caused by excavator breaking hammers, road cutters and electric hammers, the other vector consisted of MFCC, short-term energy and short-term zero-crossing rate is used for training Classiﬁer-2. The random forest algorithm used for classiﬁer training is

a machine learning algorithm proposed by Breiman [14]. Random forest is an integrated learning model assembled by multiple decision trees [20]. Each decision tree separately classiﬁes the unknown samples, and then the result of the random forest model is obtained according to the voting result of the decision trees. The training ﬂow of decision trees is as follows: (1) Randomly generate N sets TS1, TS2, …, TSN (N is equal to the number of the trained decision trees) by the Bootstrap method [21] as the training sets of N decision trees. (2) In the training ﬂow of each decision tree, m (an integer greater than 0 and less than the total number of features) features are ﬁrst se- lected from all the features as the splitting feature selection set of the current node, and then the node of the decision tree is split with the best-performing feature in the selection set. (3) Each decision tree grows completely without pruning. 5. Monitoring strategy and testing results 5.1. Monitoring strategy After training the two classiﬁers for diﬀerent purposes, a strategy for monitoring construction threats on underground pipeline can be set up, as shown in Fig. 6, which is mainly followed by the steps: (1) Sound signal collection—collecting sound signals by microphones placed along pipelines. The distances between microphones mainly depend on the eﬀective identiﬁcation range of the classiﬁer and should be adjusted according to the importance of the pipeline, the frequency of threats and the environmental noise level. In general, the distance can be set to 60 m. Fig. 5. MFCC calculation process. Table 2 Numbers of training samples. Construction threat events Range (m) Testing samples Traﬃc noise Pedestrian- induced noise Wind noise Electric hammer 5–30 4680 4700 1520 Road cutter 5–50 4240 4100 1560 Excavator breaking hammer 5–80 9100 9850 3150 No construction equipment N/A 71,980 71,350 23,770 Fig. 6. The ﬂow of monitoring system. Z. Liu and S. Li Autom ation in Construction 113 (2020) 103125 5 (2) Signal segmentation—segmenting sound records to obtain samples. The acoustic signals collected by microphones are segmented and windowed for the samples that can be identiﬁed by the two clas- siﬁers. (3) Double-layer identiﬁcation scheme—calculating the required fea- tures and identifying samples through the double-layer classiﬁer composed of classiﬁer-1 and classiﬁer-2. In the framework, the short-term energy feature and the short-term zero-rate feature of the samples are ﬁrst calculated to detect the starting and ending points of the construction threats using the classiﬁer-1. After re- cognizing the suspected threat sounds by the classiﬁer-1, the MFCC feature is calculated and combined with the short-term energy feature and the short-term zero-rate feature for the identiﬁcation of the classiﬁer-2. The classiﬁer-2 serves to review the results of classiﬁer-1 and to determine the type of construction threats. (4) Sending alarm—sending alarm to the management center based on the results from the double-layer classiﬁer. If the duration of the construction threat sound exceeds the alert value, the alarm device will upload the report to prevent construction threats. 5.2. Testing results In this section, the testing samples under diﬀerent conditions as shown in Table 3 are employed to address two issues: the capability of the monitoring system to detect threat sounds under a

variety of noise conditions and the probability of a false alarm. Two ratios are hence proposed for evaluating the testing results. The recognition rate (R) is deﬁned by: = R T T / r a (10) where Tr is the number of the detected construction threat samples; Ta is the number of all construction threat samples. The false alarm rate (F) can be calculated by: = F T T / p b (11) where Tp is the number of the environmental noise samples causing false alarm;Tb is the number of all the environmental noise samples. It can be seen from Tables 4 and 5 that the average recognized rate and the average false alarm rate of the monitoring system are 95.59% and 1.12%. The standard deviations in Table 4 and Table 5 indicate that the performance of the system is stable for diﬀerent threat events and environmental noise. All the results prove that the system can eﬀec- tively detect the construction threats around pipelines. 6. Conclusion Construction activities have posed serious threats on underground pipeline in recent years. In the framework of multi-class classiﬁcation as usually followed by a standard procedure of “collecting data—feature extraction—classiﬁer training—monitoring scheme”, this paper pre- sents a random forest-based sound monitoring system for prevention of underground pipeline damage caused by construction. The working sounds of construction equipment including excavator breaking hammers, road cutters and electric hammers are collected as the signals of typical construction threats. The three types of environ- mental noise induced by pedestrian, traﬃc and wind are also taken into account as the background noise. The core of the system is the double-layer identiﬁcation scheme that consists of two random forest-based classiﬁers. The classiﬁer-1 ﬁrst takes the short-term energy and the short-term zero-crossing rate as features for determining the starting and ending points of the suspected sounds. Then the classiﬁer-2, which is trained by including MFCC as another feature, identiﬁes the suspicious segments for checking the results of classiﬁer-1 and obtaining the types of construction threats. In virtue of the double-layer design, the proposed system can achieve high recognition rate and low consumption. In the test, the detected threat signals account for 95.59% of all threat signals, while only 1.12% of the environmental noise causes false alarms. The standard deviations of the recognition rate and the false alarm rate indicate that the performance of the system is stable for the three pipeline threats and various environmental noise. Therefore, the monitoring system performs well under diﬀerent types of environ- mental noise and can play an important role in preventing pipeline damage caused by construction.
